items.synopsis: The New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council is holding "a week of silence" to mourn the outcome of the referendum, as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags are lowered to half-mast. Follow live.

title.children: AEC rejects suggestions of interference at remote polls, as Indigenous leaders start 'week of silence'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kelly Fuller One of the leaders of the Illawarra Yes campaign, Jamie Beveridge says young First Nations people are shattered by the referendum result. “They are searching for answers, there was so much hope just around humanity prevailing and sadly that is not what we have woken up to this morning,” Ms Beveridge said. “For some they have phrased it as why does the nation hate us.” The Bindal woman and the University of Wollongong’s Vice President, Indigenous Strategy and Engagement said the result was another wound for First Nations people. “It will just be another scare, that sadly we have to work to heal,” she said. “Trans-generational trauma exists regardless of what the No campaign wanted people to believe that colonisation didn't have an effect on my people.” Ms Beveridge said she was also incredibly concerned by the misinformation used by the No campaign in the referendum. “It shows there is no governance mechanism to address false information, there is no recourse for blatantly lying and misleading the truth, and that was apparent through the No campaign,” she said. “I don't believe we are a racist nation. I just think potentially the system contributed to allowing mistruths to be the narrative.” She said she believes the No result has pushed reconciliation back years. "For our people there is going to be more distrust, not just in government, I think we will be reading rooms and counting and thinking who were our allies," she said. “We saw so many businesses, many corporations come out in support of the Yes campaign, and in the future we will hold those organsations accountable and they will have to walk the walk in spite of that outcome.” But Ms Beveridge said she still remains hopeful moving forward. “We came from a place of love, we were never about division, this was never about race, we will just keep digging deep and hope for a better tomorrow," she said. “There will be a continuation of our strength and our resilience and our hope for a better tomorrow.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Young First Nations people 'searching for answers,' Indigenous leader says

children.content: Reporting by Kelly Fuller
One of the leaders of the Illawarra Yes campaign, Jamie Beveridge says young First Nations people are shattered by the referendum result.
“They are searching for answers, there was so much hope just around humanity prevailing and sadly that is not what we have woken up to this morning,” Ms Beveridge said.
“For some they have phrased it as why does the nation hate us.”
(ABC Illawarra: Sarah Moss)
The Bindal woman and the University of Wollongong’s Vice President, Indigenous Strategy and Engagement said the result was another wound for First Nations people.
“It will just be another scare, that sadly we have to work to heal,” she said.
“Trans-generational trauma exists regardless of what the No campaign wanted people to believe that colonisation didn't have an effect on my people.”
Ms Beveridge said she was also incredibly concerned by the misinformation used by the No campaign in the referendum.
“It shows there is no governance mechanism to address false information, there is no recourse for blatantly lying and misleading the truth, and that was apparent through the No campaign,” she said.
“I don't believe we are a racist nation. I just think potentially the system contributed to allowing mistruths to be the narrative.”
She said she believes the No result has pushed reconciliation back years.
"For our people there is going to be more distrust, not just in government, I think we will be reading rooms and counting and thinking who were our allies," she said.

“We saw so many businesses, many corporations come out in support of the Yes campaign, and in the future we will hold those organsations accountable and they will have to walk the walk in spite of that outcome.”
But Ms Beveridge said she still remains hopeful moving forward.
“We came from a place of love, we were never about division, this was never about race, we will just keep digging deep and hope for a better tomorrow," she said.
“There will be a continuation of our strength and our resilience and our hope for a better tomorrow.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prominent Tasmanian Aboriginal campaigner Michael Mansell says that now the Voice has been defeated, pressure must build for other aspects of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. He's called for designated Aboriginal seats in parliament as happens in New Zealand. You can read more of his comments here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No campaigner Michael Mansell calls for designated Indigenous seats in parliament

featuredLink.title: Prominent No campaigner says Yes volunteers can now be harnessed on a new cause — Indigenous seats to parliament

children.content: Prominent Tasmanian Aboriginal campaigner Michael Mansell says that now the Voice has been defeated, pressure must build for other aspects of the Uluru Statement from the Heart.
He's called for designated Aboriginal seats in parliament as happens in New Zealand.
You can read more of his comments here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Rebecca Pridham Despite opinion polls showing Tasmania was leaning towards a Yes result, it never eventuated. Northern Tasmanians strongly voted No and out at the Evandale Sunday Markets, south of Launceston, many spoke to the ABC about what happened. Richard Baker said he saw an ad on TV that said: "If you don't know, vote No." "I didn't know, I voted No," he said. "If they wanted to win, they needed tell us what they were going to do and they would have got more Yes votes." He said he didn't think people understood what it was all about. Yes voter Max Nicholas was at the Evandale Market today and said he was "pretty disappointed". "I expected the No vote to get up but I would have liked it to go our way," he said. "I've got a pretty cynical view on people. If it's not for them personally, they don't want anything to do with it, and a lot of them don't like seeing others get something. Plus, there was a lot of misinformation and scaremongering out there." He said he didn't think the Yes campaign did a good enough job in educating people about what they were voting for. Launceston man Jim McCauley said he was "feeling a bit sad" that the referendum failed. "An Aboriginal bloke was saying to us that, 'We've always passed down our information by telling stories and listening,' and I felt that's pretty much what the Voice is about." He said he felt the referendum failed because it became politicised — "we're good and they're bad" — and the issue got "torn" with no clear message. Yes voter Veronica Stone said she wasn't surprised by the referendum result. "It was no chance [of being successful]," she said. She hit back at the No campaign's slogan saying "If you don't know, vote No". She felt there was a lot of "fearmongering" in the campaign, "and it made people not want to do the research". Barbara said it would have been better to use the money "wasted" on the referendum in areas where it was needed instead, such as the health system or schools. "We're all the same and there's no need for them to try and make a difference between us," she said. She said she was glad though that there had finally been a decision. "It wouldn't worry me either way if it had gone through," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tasmania was the first state called for No

children.content: Reporting by Rebecca Pridham
Despite opinion polls showing Tasmania was leaning towards a Yes result, it never eventuated.
Northern Tasmanians strongly voted No and out at the Evandale Sunday Markets, south of Launceston, many spoke to the ABC about what happened.

props.alt: A man holding a market stall

children.content: (ABC News: Maren Preuss)
Richard Baker said he saw an ad on TV that said: "If you don't know, vote No."
"I didn't know, I voted No," he said.
"If they wanted to win, they needed tell us what they were going to do and they would have got more Yes votes."
He said he didn't think people understood what it was all about.

props.alt: A man in front of a van looking sad

children.content: (ABC News: Maren Preuss)
Yes voter Max Nicholas was at the Evandale Market today and said he was "pretty disappointed".
"I expected the No vote to get up but I would have liked it to go our way," he said.

"I've got a pretty cynical view on people. If it's not for them personally, they don't want anything to do with it, and a lot of them don't like seeing others get something. Plus, there was a lot of misinformation and scaremongering out there."
He said he didn't think the Yes campaign did a good enough job in educating people about what they were voting for.
Launceston man Jim McCauley said he was "feeling a bit sad" that the referendum failed.
"An Aboriginal bloke was saying to us that, 'We've always passed down our information by telling stories and listening,' and I felt that's pretty much what the Voice is about."
He said he felt the referendum failed because it became politicised — "we're good and they're bad" — and the issue got "torn" with no clear message.

props.alt: a woman wiht green hair, black lips at a market

children.content: (ABC News: Maren Preuss)
Yes voter Veronica Stone said she wasn't surprised by the referendum result.
"It was no chance [of being successful]," she said.
She hit back at the No campaign's slogan saying "If you don't know, vote No".
She felt there was a lot of "fearmongering" in the campaign, "and it made people not want to do the research".

props.alt: A woman in front of a display case

children.content: (ABC News: Maren Preuss)
Barbara said it would have been better to use the money "wasted" on the referendum in areas where it was needed instead, such as the health system or schools.
"We're all the same and there's no need for them to try and make a difference between us," she said.
She said she was glad though that there had finally been a decision.
"It wouldn't worry me either way if it had gone through," she said.

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirms that a mixture of government-chartered and military planes will depart Tel Aviv today for Australians wishing to leave. Follow live.

title.children: Repatriation flights from Israel are likely to take off today, Penny Wong says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong during a press conference in Adelaide said that the travel advice for Lebanon has changed. "The existing travel advice for Lebanon is reconsider your need to travel due to the security environment. "I am now saying to Australians if you are in Lebanon on, you should consider whether your need to remain there is essential," Ms Wong said. "If you wish to leave you should know that a crisis could limit commercial options for departure and you should consider the first available option." If you need emergency consular assistance contact the emergency consular centre operating on a 24-hour basis on 1300 555 135 (within Australia), or +61 2 6261 3305 (from anywhere in the world) .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Foreign Minister Penny Wong asks Australians in Lebanon to consider if their need to remain there is essential

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong during a press conference in Adelaide said that the travel advice for Lebanon has changed.
"The existing travel advice for Lebanon is reconsider your need to travel due to the security environment.
"I am now saying to Australians if you are in Lebanon on, you should consider whether your need to remain there is essential," Ms Wong said.
"If you wish to leave you should know that a crisis could limit commercial options for departure and you should consider the first available option."
If you need emergency consular assistance contact the emergency consular centre operating on a 24-hour basis on
1300 555 135 (within Australia), or
+61 2 6261 3305 (from anywhere in the world)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says multiple repatriation flights for Australians stuck in Israel and the West Bank may be able to take-off from Tel Aviv today. She wrote on social media the situation in the area continues to change rapidly, and the flights are subject to the deteriorating security environment in the region. Yesterday, the Department of Foreign Affairs cancelled scheduled flights due to depart this weekend due to security concerns.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government planning multiple repatriation flights from Tel Aviv today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says multiple repatriation flights for Australians stuck in Israel and the West Bank may be able to take-off from Tel Aviv today.
She wrote on social media the situation in the area continues to change rapidly, and the flights are subject to the deteriorating security environment in the region.
Yesterday, the Department of Foreign Affairs cancelled scheduled flights due to depart this weekend due to security concerns.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel. The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel. Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel". The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza. "The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement. He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pentagon says US is sending a second aircraft carrier to the region

children.content: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel.

The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel.
Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel".
The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza.

"The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement.
He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Charlo …" Tszyu says mockingly in the ring, tapping the belt he has taken from the former undisputed champion. "He'll probably think in his delusional head that he would beat me. "Come get it. "Let's prove to everyone who is king of this division."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Come get it': Tim Tszyu sends message to Jermell Charlo

children.content: "Charlo …" Tszyu says mockingly in the ring, tapping the belt he has taken from the former undisputed champion.
"He'll probably think in his delusional head that he would beat me.
"Come get it.
"Let's prove to everyone who is king of this division."
